div.head: Leoni: A Legend of Italy
div.p: The Lord of the castle of castle's name is old, and grey headed Fourscore years have pastflitted over him, silently and anawares and the dream of life is nigh to its awaking, and his ear is dull, and his eye is dim, and his heart is weary.

The old man reclines on a couch in the hall of his ancestors. and beside an open casement, and the balmy air that dri floats over the deep blue waters of the broad sea passes softly over his gleaming hair; and his weary eye rests on the brightness of an exceeding lovely landscape for the olive and the orange and the myrtle are green by the shore of the still waters, and the city gleams whitely beneath the glance of the sun as he rides through the cloudless azure of the heaven, and the purple mountains clasp the ocean in their arms, and fade away into the horizon in long lines of misty blue.

Alas, the spring time of nature is a mockery to the winter of old age, and the old man turns away in sadness He is begirt by His vassals are waiting around him to do his pleasure, the minstrel is there with his harp. the maiden with her song, but no music is so sweet to the old mans ear as the voice of his daughter Giulietta. Giulietta , when a babe, was a thing of smiles and loveliness like a happy thought dancing over the mind------ Giulietta, when a child, was like the orange blossom in the groves of Friuli, and gladness floated around her like the fragrance of the flower. Giulietta in her youth is the fairest maiden of Italy, she glanceds among the myrtle bowers like the waywardwinged zephyr, the evening star when it trembles over rises gleaming out of the sea into the darkness of the glorious night of Italy is not so bright as the lig beam that flashes from her large eye through the night of her lovely eye lashes.

Like music to the sadness of the soul, so was Giulietta to the old age of her Father, as she passed before him a light came into the coldness of his eye, and his ear when it was dead to other sound, awoke to the murmur of her gentle voice. (Giuliettas mind was love, all love continual love to each and every thing, the birds knew Giulietta, (the nightingale sang at her chamber window his song to the stars,) and (as she walked among the flowers they fluttered beside her. and stooped their glossy necks to her hand) nay, the flowers seemed to know Giulietta and to be gladdened into brightness as she past, and Giulietta loved them all.) To her father --as an angel watches over the last days of a saint upon the earth, when the tumult of the battle of his life is oer, and sheds peace around his hours and bids his days pass sweetly and holily, so Giulietta watched over the old man like an influence of good and was the sun of his thoughts, and the light of his rejoicing.

Giulietta had a brother; Garcio
was a man of a dark countenances and the shadows of his evil passions past over it like clouds over the luridness of the stormy heaven; and his look withered those upon whom it fell, and his wrath once excited raged like a pestilence, and would not be appeased, he was feared by all, hated by many, loved by few, but his arm was restless in the battle, and his fame was bright amoung the proud names of the warriors of Italy
Among his many enemies. Garcio hated none as he did the bandit Leoni, for him only he feared;

There are spirits moving on the earth, which are not of a like order with their fellows, which will rise above the ordinary dust of mortality, whether it be in greatness of evil, or of good, and it depends upon the accident of impulse, upon the treatment of their fellow men, whether their greatness isbe a blessing or a curse. and such was Leoni, (& was what he abhorred,) for (his noble nature had been borne down by the violence of his passions), but yet his name was pronounced with fear, but not with scorn or contumely, and widely was the fear of that name spread. for he passed over the land like a meteor and left desolation behind him in the halls of the great and the poweful, but not in the hamlets of the poor.

Returning from a successful attack on the castle of a neighbouring baron, Leoni had been once tracked to the fastnesses of the Apennines by Garcio, with a chosen troop of his followers. the bandit gave him battle, and was as usual victorious, the followers of Garcio cowered back from the charge of the bandithis thunderbolt chargeGarcioand he andGarcio himself was struck from his horse by the sword of of their leaderLeoni It had been said of Leoni that he had never spared deserted a friend, or spared an enemy. but suddenly as his sword waved over the head of his prostrate foe, the beaver of Garcios helmet fell open his arm was checked as if by the hand of an invisible being* and to the astonishment of his followers, Leoni sounded a retreat in the very flush of victory and theGarcio and his band w disheartened and vanquished band were suffered to retire unmolested.

*a smile of scorn passed over his lip, and then a mildness came into the flash of his eye, a mildness nevernever before seen on the features of Leoni; he turned calmly away, and to the astonishment &c

From that time the hatred of Garcio to Leoni was as a consuming fire, and the shame of defeat and the thirst of revenge gnawed into his heart like vultures--he had rather have been laid dead by the sword of Leoni than suffered to live a monument of the clemency of this bandit conqueror
Giulietta. Giulietta. said the old man

And Giulietta came forth from among her maidens like the when it is bright among the pale stars and she knelt down silentlysoftly besides her parent, and lifted up her large eyes full of love. And a blessing past silently over the heart of her father in and descended upon her like the dew of C

Giulietta , said the old man, there is a dark spirit upon me to day, a shadow that is felt, a dread stillness of the mind like the fearful hush of the air before the desolation of the earthquake, a chill is upon my soul as if the hand of death was or were lying cold even upon my mind
Nay, my father, said Giulietta, thou art weary, and she bent over him and kissed his cheek

p.said: I am not weary when thou art beside me Giulietta, this gloom that sits brooding over my heart is not weakness or disease, it is a presentiment of evil which the invisible beings who are round us in the air and in us, and who watch over our feelings and turn them to good or to evil, have power to infuse into our souls as a warning--Such there are, Giulietta, I have spoken with them in my mind. I have felt their power ruling over my life. I have felt them busy about my heartstrings in Joy or in sorrow--

div.p: My father, said Giulietta, the evil spirits have no power over us without our own consent, and this midnight of the soul is not of the good.
I know not, returned the old man, I have felt it once before it was followed by the death of those whom I loved.
Giulietta looked up, and her fathershis countenance was exceeding pale, and there was a horror upon it of great fear.
My Father, my Father, said Giulietta speak not so you are ill said Giuliettathe maiden

No, Giulietta I believe I shall not see that sun set That sun will soon set I believe Giulietta, and to me I believe said the old man, but this is not the for ever death, nor the fear of death, that sits so heavily on me. What is it to one like me to fall asleep from weariness of life--why should I fear resting from trouble and griefturmoil and grief, why should a gloom come over me from the dread of repose.
What do you fear, my father, said Giulietta
I know not what I fear but I fear for thee only, my daughter, said the old man, the only blow which can now reach my old heart, must be struck through thee. Leave me--Giulietta.
Not thus, not thus. said the maiden, for the countenance of her father grew still paler.

p.said: Yes--Ieave me, thy presence but increases this horror that has bound me--farewell

div.p: And the maiden kissed her fathers brow. and it was very cold. and his frame trembled strongly. and she left him, and sought her chamber in sorrow.

The sun is low in the heaven, and the tall rocks on the sea shore are reddened with his rays, and the columns of the ruined temple on their summit throw their shadows lengthily along their sward By a narrow path on the face of the grey rocks a band of warriors was defiling man by man, and the warm rays glanced gaily on their crested helms. High was the brow and lofty the glance of their leader. and a pride sat upon his lip; sus for the countenance of Leoni was not as the countenance of other men, the emotions which passed over his heart like whirlwinds, mo were not reflected in the stillness of his brow none when they looked upon Leoni could have known what thoughts were passing over working in the deep secret places of his soul. Neither hope, nor fear, nor anger had ever been seen on his countenance, and when but the pride of spirit sat there ever, and when he spoke, even in the
One of his followers was beside him, privileged by superior age, one whom Leoni had allowed to speak familiarly to him and as a friend. and the old mans tone was querulous and complaining.

p.said: Lo, we are to wait here for you again half the night we are we. I love not these solitary rambles of yours, Leoni, what can you have to do alone at the castle of castle's name every evening;

div.p: Trouble not yourself about methat, Anselmo, said Leoni, kindly.

But I do trouble myself, returned Anselmo, I love not to be left here sprawling idle on this damp grass every night while you go pushing your head into the Lions mouth in this way I can't imagine what makes you keep lurking alone about that castle of castle's name unless it be to let Garcio catch you. and then you would lose your head, and we our captain
Fear not for me, said Leoni, my doom is not to die by his coward sword--

I don't know that Leoni, replied the old man. that was another fools trick of yours, you should have known better, when he fell before you in the battle, than to think that a coward he would ever have forgiven his defeat Why did you let him live to plot means of revenge as a reward for your verymost wise clemency;
Leoni smiled in scorn.

I knew him then as I know him now, he said Let him plot against me as he will--think you I care for his coward wrath meanly devised revenge or coward and impotent wrath. Garcio is to me as the wave that dashes its weak spray on the forehead of yonder stern and unyielding crag.

p.said: Nevertheless Leoni, if he were to catch you near his castle without your followers, I fancy our next charge on him would not be unheaded by you be without a leader You had better stay here out of the Lionshis den. or take us with you--Ill follow you to the castle with the utmost possible pleasure-- and when hes down here providing you don't sound a retreat as you so prudently did once when we were about to give the rascals a lesson how they tracked thedared to attack the band of Leoni --you were possessed that day Leoni, mad, quite mad. some of them would have remembered it as long as their heads stood on their shoulders

div.p: Not yetYou must not follow me, said Leoni, you may have an must remain here one this evening at least but keep your carbines loaded, and sleep not. I may have need of you this night.

Its high time I know, muttered Anselmo, to have need of us, we might as well be fishermen or Lazzaroni at once as lie here like moon calves all th night, not a blow to be struck nor a shot fired. Well, if he will go he will-- must, I suppose. he'll be tired of this in time or somebody Garcio will teach him the imprudence of solitary contemplation. And with a low discontented kind of growl Anselmo couched sulkily behind a fallen column looked to the priming of his carbine, turned his sword belt round that the hilt might be near his hand, and (etc) The rest of the band werehad soon disappeared into various places of concealment. and Leoni leaping down lightly from the rocks, with a light step purs moved rapidly along the seashore towards the castle of-- castle's name And a change came over his countenance and it grew mild. and a gladness rested on it. and the haughtiness of his lip faded away

Giulietta sat in her chamber, in the eastern tower of the castle of castle's name and the evening was sinking down upon the shores of the deep sea. And Giulietta's eye rested and the evening star as it rose up out of the deep and climbed slowly up into the darkening sky. and far through the deep blue air gleamed its melancholy ray. and shone paly on the quivering countenance of the moving waters And Giuliettas large dark eye rested sadly on the star, and what were Giuliettas thoughts. and now fast waned the daylight away and the glow of the sky that was shed oer it by the departing sun became cold, and the shadow of the pervading starlight became visible on the chequered floor and marblecarved walls and carved ceilin of the chamber. And the objects beneath night came glorious down upon the sea.

And the star climbed higher and higher. and as it vanished behindtouched the summit of a distantthe mountain the night breeze came balmily over the deep. and as it balm died away athe voice was heard singing below the castle. And Giulietta drew near the window and listened, and the sounds camerose softly up upon the wings of the night wind and G the moon and the stars were the only witnesses of the looked down, and saw a blush that passed over Giuliettas lovely cheek, for the voice was Francesco and thus it sang. the voice

lg.l: There was a tower within my heart
The tower was high and strong and high
But oh, its walls they fell before
The glance of thy bright eye
A throne of love withing the tower
A lofty throne, was seen
And there thou sittest on the throne
Indisputable queen
Full high upon the Apennine
Is set my mountain town
And there with gems and marble fine
I've decked a lady's bower
The lady's bower is fair to see
No Ladys there I ween
Oh maiden, wend away with me
And thou shalt be its queen.
And far among the mountains blue
I have a trusty band
My band is bold, my band is true
They wait for my command
Their hands are strong their hearts are free
Their swords are bright and keen
Oh maiden, wend away with me
And thou shalt be their queen

div.p: And the voice faded awaydied away, and the tones passed away drearily into the stillness of the night

And the voice song ceased, and the tones passed away into the stillness of the night; Giulietta opened a secret door and descended, and Francesco saw her come forth into the night in her beauty; robed all in a robe of light. What meant thy song to night Francescosaid the maiden What can a farewell to thee mean Giulietta, but misery-- And why farewell, said Giulietta, and she looked enquiringly at her lover, and there was an agony passing over his high foreheadcountenance, and the damp deathlike dew sat hung upon his forehead. Why farewell, he repeated, ay. why farewell between thee and me, thisit cannot shall not be.
Why this, Francesco. Whither wouldest thou go Francesco said Giulietta.

p.said: Ask the withered leaf that is torn quivering from its bough and drifted at the will of the winters wind--ask the meteor that is hurled irregularly down among the stars--ask the pray of the ocean when the tempest whirls it along the shore where they would go, for withered as the autumn leaf and vain as the ocean spray, and desolating and feared as the influence of the fires of the night, shall I be Giulietta, when parted from thee

div.p: This is madness Francesco, replied the maiden, wherefore must we part, or if we must, how canst thou noble and true as I have known thee, become the thing thou hast described. Thou knowest me not Giulietta--I am not noble--I am not true
Mock me not--thou art Francesco Giuliettathe maiden--

p.said: I could be. I will be, Giulietta. we will not part--fly with me--the night is down on the mountains--my band is near--ere the day dawns we shall be far hence in safety--in honour, ay if thou wilt--in power.

div.p: Thy band, the maiden Giuliettarepeated --fly with thee-- with whom What art thou what mean you, Francesco.

I know not, maiden, said Francesco and he laughed I have not been what not I seem to be--yet thou could'st make me so. With thee I am Francesco--without thee I am a walking misery. the curse of others, and a deeper curse of my own heart --an corporealembodied fever of reckless madness the pestilence, the scourge, the deeper curse of my own heart--in one word, without thee I am Leoni.

And the word struck through to the maidens heart with a coldness as of death, and the cry she formedwould have uttered died upon her lips, and she fainted in the arms of her Lover Oh how beautiful was the fear upon Giuliettas faces--as she lay in the lifeless sleep, pale as the snow that lies beneath the moon upon the high Apennine and the terror on aher countenance was as the terror of troubled slumber--

Then the hectic flush passed over her cheek, and she woke from the partial death with a deep gasp as of one in pain and her dark eye gleamed with a vague uncertain horror--And she passed her hand over her pale brow. and lo--it was as the silver cloud that passeth over the brow of Monte Rosa --brightness of the midnight moon-- Francesco. Francesco, she said, thou toldest me something--it was terrible--tell it me again-- Francesco where art thou thou art not Francesco--you said you were not--Francesco is dead--dead--she not And she paused for a moment. I know now, she said. I remember--well--very well. Francesco is dead. and thou art Leoni--the bandit Leoni*. Oh fly--fly for thy life Leoni--I love thee yet-- Garcio will find thee will kill thee--my brother will kill thee Francesco.

Thou art not, thou canst not--thou shalt not be Leoni the bandit Leoni. my brothers enemy to the death--Oh Francesco --say thou mockest me. I was once Leoni, he replied-- thy brothers enemy never--had I been Garcio had now not lived--Giulietta, you cannot believe I could be the enemy of your brother-- He is thine she replied, oh fly, fly for--&c

Let him, said Leoni--bitterly-- fly without thee--Giulietta I will not I could not. Die-- how I could thank death for the blow if it were not that beyond the grave there might I know not if there might not be forgetfulness--forgetfulness of thee Giulietta--he paused--that were worse than the life without thee- -but death could not do that no. no. my spirit would be with thee then Giuletta [sic} upon earth. the air evening breeze that fanned thy cheek should be Leoni--the nightingale should sing byin the orange grove, and Leoni should bear the sound to thy ear--and the fragrance of the wild rose should be brought thee by Leoni--the wreath of the morning mist the lightbealight of the noonday sun, the beam of the evening star should all be full of Leoni, and who should separate thee from these--Would not this be happiness, Giulietta Oh Giulietta, either fly with me this night, or I will remain here, and the Sword of Garcio shall unite me with thee for ever--Who shall slay an invisible--who shall part thee from the air And Giulietta knewfelt that it was Francesco, and not Leoni, who spoke, and she paused in very great agony.

Great was the tumult in the castle of castle's name an old peasant (who had been gathering sticks amid the thickets on the sea shore at the foot of the castle) had come to Garcio saying that he seen [sic] (, one of whichthem was a maiden of exceeding beauty,) two figures passing down westward towar on the sea shore, they had passed himat the foot of the castle he had seen them pass unobserved, the countenance of the other he said was one which he knew well, one which once seen was not easily forgotten, that of Leoni the bandit Then Garcio was wild with rage & he he called his followers together, and the clash of arms was loud in the hall--and then from the gate issued a troop of armed men warriors, and their arms gleamed coldly in the pale moonstarlight--and Garcio spurred on his bloody warhorse in the van--and his countenance was pale with the wrath, and he dashed madly forward along the winding shore

But one of the maidens of Giulietta, when she heard the peasants tale, went and sought for Giulietta in her chamberfathers hall and she was not there, and in her fathers chamber, and she was not there. and she descended by the secret staircase and she saw footsteps in the dew on the grassy ground. Then she returned weeping--and she came to the old m her father of Giulietta, and she told him that Leoni the bandit had carried her away Giulietta And the old man was weak, and very feeble-- and he could not grieve and hise bowed his head gently upon his breast and died.

And the spirit went forth with a complaining, and passed moaning on the night wind in search of those whom it loved--And it fledwent fast like a wreath of sea mist along the shore and came and hovered over the head of Giulietta, as she fled with Leoni, and as the spirit came near unto her she remembered her father and how he had said that the sun would not rise to him-And she stopped in great misery, exclaiming--oh my father, my father surely I have murdered thee my father--Then she heard her through her weeping the noise of a soft sigh beside her-and she started and looked round--it was not like the voice of the wind among the mur laurel leaves, neither like the murmer of the little waves upon the shore And she said to Leoni Heardest thou nothing she said to Leoni.

Nothing. Giulietta, he replied-- nay--now that I listen, methinks I hear the traa sound far away like the tramp of steeds along the sand. And she Giulietta listened, and she was filled with great fear. ah fly Leoni, she said, it is Garcio. fly, and leave me here--

But Leoni raised her in his arms, and bore her softly forward. and Giulietta overcame her faintness, and struggled onward, and they fled. And now the rocks were seen rising high from the sea shore, and the columns of the ruined temple were seen upon this summit, and Leoni knew that his band was near. On. On. One effort more Giulietta he said exclaimed, and we are safe. And now the tramp of the galloping horses came nearer and nearer and the voices of men were heard urging them on. Louder and louder became the sound, and Leoni Giulietta made one last struggle forward--and they gained the rocks, they stood beneath the ruined temple-- Anselmo--Anselmo, cried Leoni aloud and he was answered by a shout from the cliffs, and the bandits leaped from their concealment but as they gained the shore the foremost horseman of the opposite troop dashed like lightning into view--it was Garcio --a shout of triumph burst from his lips when he saw Leoni--Giulietta saw him level his carbine--with a shriek of agony she threw herself before Leoni , and fell dead into his arms, and the dying sigh that came from her lips sounded like--Francesco--

The band of Leoni heard the shot, and were round him in an instant, and lo their leader was standing beside the body of a maiden and the calm upon his countenance was dreadful. and there was a smile upon his lips like the grinning of the dry bones of a withered skull. and there was a stillness in his eye, and on his features, but it was as the stillness of the volcano before it bursts forth into desolation And his troops stood round him in a fearful silence--

There was a pause until, like a whirlwind over the quietness of deep waters came the madness over the soul of Leoni--and he looked, and saw that his band was beside him--. and he saidStand by me this night, he said, and revenge you the loss of your leader--And Then he shouted his warshout aloud, and the bandits swelled the sound with eager voices, and as the followers of Garcio replied Leoni dashed at them like a thunderbolt.

Then loudly into the quietness of the heaven rose the roar of the battle, and the echoes rolled heavily over the sea. On came the bandits like the tornado in its power, and the banner of Garcio bore backward shivering, but he cheered them again to the onset, and the tumult bellowed along the shore as the and the shots rang loud and thick from among the volumes of smoke lit by the death flashes that coiled its heavy and sulphurous mass into the choked sky heaven-- Like the light that trembles along the rippled waters of the ocean with itsa thousand sparkles, gleamed sabre the flashing sabres amid the darkness of the war--but the clash of the weapons and the roar of the fire were not mingled with any voice--for the combatants could not shout in the madness of the struggle, and the wounded fell in indignant silence and gasped out their souls without a groan--

With the inveterate wrath of anthe avenging spirit of the victim pursing its murderer, did &Leoni burst his path through the ba mass of battle, and heis watched thebloodshot eye was on the crest of Garcio as it rose and fell on the billowy burst of the war, and whether it were friend or foe whom he met in his madness, he dashed the combatants aside in death and clove his way onward toward that high helmet of his one enemyplume And with the inveterate wrath of an avenging spirit, when the dark ghost of the victim walks the earth in the pursuit of its murderer, Leoni follo sought his single foe-- And the followers of Leoni Garcio shrunk back even from his glance, and as he broke into the through the fore-front of their battle some turned their backs and fled, and the rest hung back in disorder and dismay. Then the bandits drew backward out of the rush of the battle like the dark reflux of a mighty billow before it breaks upon the shore, they paused for a moment, a murmur so came rose from their ranks, louder and louder became the voice, and then with a shout that startled the very stars they broke down upon their hesitating opponents.

And the shock was as the shock of an ocean, and irresistible, and the ranks of Garcio were overwhelmed and broken, in an instant, and wild was the tumult as they were driven backwards and struck down. Then Garcio saw Leoni come upon with the swoop of an eagle. and his eye quailed and his limb quivered, before the despair of his op foe--
Wretch, cried Leoni, lovest thou life--Oh, would that I could make thy life to thee what thou hast made it to me--and thou shouldst live--
I spared thee once, for her sake--thou hast well rewarded me--Thy sister strikes thee--Garcio--And he smote him dead.

And the voice of battle drifted away towards the castle of castle's name and the shouts of the victorious bandits were heard echoing along the cliffs. but Leoni was no longer at their head--in their victory they were without a leader--they remembered how he had commanded them to avenge his loss; and few, very few of the followers of Garcio escaped the slaughter of that night--and the flames soon rose redly from wrapt themselves round the towers of the castle, and wrapt it round and shone redly and far over the darkness of the ocean And the bandits met by the lurid light of the rushing fire and sought for Leoni among the dead, and they found the body of Garcio--and the sword of their leader lying beside it--but him they found not, and they retired silently under cover of the night to their fastness among the mountains.

Oh, calmly brightly beautifully the morning rose up out of the eastern sea--and widely spread the rosy glorydawn over the deep--Gloriously the radiance stole up into the high heaven--and the white clouds waved their light wings in the deepness of its infinite blue, and looked out eastward rejoicing as they met the morning breeze that sprang upward from its repose in the olive grove of silver olives--and it breathed on the pale clouds and itthey passed silently on their path to meet the sun

And the sun lifted his head majestically out of the sea, and looked forth upon the world, and the mists rolled away before the his glance from the surface of the sea--and the waters walked in light, and the waves passed onward surging with sweet low voices, and the sun laid along the surges a long golden path even unto the shore
And the mountains saw his glory and were gladdened--and their steeps were bathed in brightness--

Oh the radiance of that morning was unconscious of the desolation of the night, there was no sadness in the brilliancy of the dawn that shone on the ruins of the castle and the voices of the winds and the waters was gay, and the surges that had dashed away the blood from the shore through the night now broke clear and white on the unstained pebbles And the columns of the ruined temple on the shorerocks stood tall in the beam, and broadly and darkly against the gleaming sky rose the tall trunks and spreading foliage of the ancient trees. A figure was leaning against one of the rocks on the sea shore, and wan and haggard was theits countenance as if it had been withered th away by the devouring fire that flickered in madly in the eye; Few, very few, could have recognized in the weary face and withered form the once bearing of the haughty and fiery Leoni-- and the fishermen of Pozuolo affirm that for years after that terrible night the same figure was seen wandering among the rocks upon the shore with sleepless eye and weary limb, and with w lookingwalking among the crags as if seeking something, he know not what with the restlessness of madness passing hither and thither at all times, whether the night winds were singing mournfullysadly or the stars gleaming tearfully, or the morn breaking brightly, or the sun setting silently over the resting place of the Bandits bride.

And when were [sic] Giulietta's thoughts. She was listening f waiting for a voice that rose every evening as the star disappeared behind the summit of a distant peaked mountain from the myrtle Grove beneath the castles [sic]. Giulietta hardly knew how very sweet the voice was to her ear--for it was the voice of one who loved her with a more than common love--even with a love like that of spirits. They had first met when Giulietta was young, very young, and Francesco a youth just verging into manhood--From that hour she had been like a halo of glory in the life of Francesco--Giulietta knew it, she could not help loving one him whose thoughts whose hopes, whose being were centred in her only-- she the thought of her she came upon his spiritsoul like the morning on the dark mountains --Francesco thought not how black would be the midnight if that sun should ever set

The thought of her came over his soul like the morning on dark mountains--and when absent from her, Francesco had two lives, and one was cold, and dead, and dark, & cheerless, but the other was a visionarythe dreamy life of the mind, beautiful exceedingly, full of light and loveliness, for the vision of her was there always

Her father knew not of the love of his child--Francesco had seen her only at intervals for moments, by stealth, pleading to Giulietta some ancient feud of their families as an excuse for maintaining the his love in secret --Several times in the masque or the dance at the castle of-- a knight had mingled of more graceful form and nobler bearinq--none knew him--unless there was recognition in the brightness of Giuliettas eye-several times when her fathershe had gone forth with her father & a retinue of fifty knights the ranks had been thrown into confusion as if by a supernumerary individually--Giulietta only knew how--several times when the minstrels were singing in the hall had one come forward of haughtier glance and loftier brow, and all bent forward to hearlisten to his strain, but the lay of love, charming all ears, intended only for one--
The song ceased for a moment, and then again the perfumed night breeze became vocal--but now the sounds were low and sad-- and fell coldlymelancholy on Giuliettas ear--

lg.l: Now broad and brilliant lies the light
Of moon and stars on flood and fell
But in my breast is starless night
For I have come to say farewell--
How glad, how swift was wont to be
The step that bore me back to thee
Now coldly comes upon my heart
The meeting that is but to part--
I do not ask a tear. but while
I linger where I must not stay,
Oh, give me but a parting smile
Eleven lines, to the bottom of the page, are left blank; the
remaining text begins at the top of the following recto.
To light me on my lonely way
To shine, a brilliant beacon star
To my reverted glance afar--
Through midnight, which can have no morrow
Oer the deep, silent surge of sorrow
The ardent fire within me flashes-And
though my heart consumed may be
There is a Phoenix in its ashes--
Oh how I love the love of thee--
Although my hope anbe chill and joy be chill
That constant flame will flicker still
And round my broken heart will play
With mocking melancholy ray
